head.title: Summing Up: Is Our House Divided by Race?; Hungry for History

hedline.hl1: Summing Up: Is Our House Divided by Race?; Hungry for History

abstract.p: William Loren Katz letter on poll reported in July 11 article comments on desire among African-Americans for more teaching of black history

block.p: Re ''Poll Finds Optimistic Outlook but Enduring Racial Division'' (front page, July 11):
Re ''Poll Finds Optimistic Outlook but Enduring Racial Division'' (front page, July 11):
Your poll found that 81 percent of African-Americans feel that the amount of black history taught in public schools is ''just right'' and that only 13 percent feel that it is ''too little.''
As someone who has lectured on black history for more than 30 years, often to largely African-American audiences, I find the 81-13 percent split surprising.

During my question-and-answer periods, audience members invariably pose these questions: ''Why isn't this taught in our schools?'' ''How can we get this information into school courses?'' and ''Do you think this kind of information will ever become part of the school curriculum?''

As speakers offer these questions, something remarkable happens: many African-Americans (and some whites) quietly nod or lean forward to hear the answers. Given my experience, these questions represent the concerns of far more than the 13 percent your poll found.
WILLIAM LOREN KATZ New York, July 13, 2000
